P.title: Will the price of water on the NQH20 hit $2,500 (2021 USD) per acre-foot by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the price of water hits $2500, adjusted for inflation to 2021 USD, on the NQH20 by 2050-01-01, 00:00 UTC. This question resolves negatively if the price of water does not hit $2500 by that date, and it resolves ambiguously if the NQH20 or a similar exchange doesn't continuously track California water prices up until 2050

P.title: If Joe Biden is elected president of the US in 2020, will the highest tax bracket be restored to its original 39.6% or higher before 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Joe Biden is elected president for the 2021-2024 term, and the upper tax bracket for US single tax payers is increased to at least 39.6% by January 1, 2025. If Biden is elected but the upper tax bracket is not increased to at least 39.6%, this question will resolve as No.
If Biden is not elected President in 2020, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

P.title: Will smoking and sex be less prevalent in the United States in 2050 than in 2021?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys of US adults in the year 2050 report that the share of adults who have smoked in the past week and the share of adults who have had sex in the past week were both lower than in the year 2021. Comparisons between 2050 and 2021 must be of similar methodology (see fine print) to count towards resolution. If no comparable surveys can be found for both smoking and sex by the resolution date of December 31, 2054, this question will resolve as Ambiguous. This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys would result in positive resolution, conflicting surveys will be considered irrelevant.
Fine Print
Regarding similar methodology, if a survey in 2021 includes e-cigarettes and a survey from 2050 does not the surveys would not be considered to have similar methodology. However, different methodologies can still be acceptable if it can be logically deduced that the surveys provide evidence toward resolution. For example, if a survey in 2021 asked whether respondents had sex in the past year and 25% answered no, and a survey in 2050 asked if respondents had sex in the past five years and 40% answered no, it can be deduced that a larger share of adults in 2050 had not had sex in the past year than in 2021 because the five year period would include the past year.

For example, if a 2021 survey asked respondents if they had sexual intercourse in the past year and 25% answered no, while a 2050 survey asked if they had sexual intercourse in the last five years and 40% answered no, it can be inferred that a larger proportion of adults in 2050 had not engaged in sexual intercourse in the past year compared to 2021, since the five-year period includes the past year.

P.title: Will the rate of smoking and sexual activity among adults in the United States be lower by 2050 than it was in 2021?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be considered true if any credible surveys conducted among adults in the US in 2050 show that both the percentage of adults who smoked in the past week and the percentage of adults who participated in sexual activity in the past week are less than the figures recorded in 2021. Comparisons between 2050 and 2021 must employ similar methodologies (see the fine print) to be regarded as valid for resolution. If no comparable surveys can be found for both smoking and sexual activity by the resolution deadline of December 31, 2054, this question will be categorized as Ambiguous. This inquiry will resolve as Yes if any trustworthy surveys yield a positive result, while contradictory surveys will be deemed irrelevant.

P.title: Will there be adversarial use of consumer genomic data before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the New York Times (or another similarly reputable source) reports, before January 1 2030, on the following having occurred:
Genetic data collected through either medical testing or direct-to-consumer products
Is used to inflict harm on one or more individuals
Without their consent
Fine Print
Recognizing that "harm" and "consent" can be fuzzy, here are some examples meant to clarify the intent of the question.
The following examples do not count as positive resolutions:
Speculation that such a harm is possible, plausible, or likely
Genetic data is leaked or hacked but there is no evidence about specific harmful uses resulting from this.
Genetic data is collected in a bespoke way for the purposes of harm (eg a state power collects DNA from a targeted individual).
Individuals suffer psychic harm from discovering family infidelities (this is so common already that it is "baked in" to consent).
The following examples do count as positive resolutions:
Evidence of discrimination or insurance rates being set from individual-level genomics without explicit customer authorization ("would you like to submit your DNA profile to Anthem?"), even if legal and authorized under a vague terms of service
An outside actor gaining access to genomics data, learning about family infidelities, and publishing this broadly.

para_P.title: Will consumer genomic data be used maliciously before 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be answered with Yes if a reputable source, such as the New York Times, reports before January 1, 2030, that the following has taken place:
Genetic information obtained through medical testing or direct-to-consumer services
Is utilized to cause harm to one or more individuals
Without their permission
Fine Print
Acknowledging that "harm" and "permission" can be ambiguous, here are some examples intended to clarify the meaning of the question.
The following examples do not count as positive resolutions:
Speculation that such harm could be possible, plausible, or likely
Genetic data is compromised or stolen but there is no proof of specific harmful applications resulting from this.
Genetic information is gathered specifically for harmful purposes (e.g., a government entity collects DNA from a targeted person).
Individuals experience emotional distress from uncovering family secrets (this is so common that it is considered part of the consent process).
The following examples do count as positive resolutions:
Proof of discrimination or insurance premiums being determined from individual-level genomic data without clear customer consent ("would you be willing to provide your DNA profile to Anthem?"), even if it is legal and authorized under vague terms of service
An external party obtaining access to genomic data, discovering family secrets, and disseminating this information widely.

Speculation regarding the potential, feasibility, or likelihood of such harm
Genetic data is breached or hacked without evidence of specific harmful consequences resulting from it.
Genetic data is gathered in a targeted manner for malicious intents (e.g., a governmental body collects DNA from a particular individual).
Individuals experience emotional distress from discovering family secrets (this is so common that it is considered inherent to consent).
The following scenarios do qualify as positive resolutions:
Proof of discrimination or insurance premiums being established based on individual genomic data without explicit customer consent (e.g., "Would you like to share your DNA profile with Anthem?"), even if it is legal and permitted under ambiguous terms of service
An external party obtaining access to genomic data, disclosing family secrets, and broadly disseminating this information.

para_P.title: Will consumer genomic data be used maliciously before 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the New York Times (or another similarly reputable source) reports, before January 1 2030, on the following having occurred:
Genetic data collected through either medical testing or direct-to-consumer products
Is used to inflict harm on one or more individuals
Without their consent
Fine Print
Recognizing that "harm" and "consent" can be fuzzy, here are some examples meant to clarify the intent of the question.
The following examples do not count as positive resolutions:
Speculation that such a harm is possible, plausible, or likely
Genetic data is leaked or hacked but there is no evidence about specific harmful uses resulting from this.
Genetic data is collected in a bespoke way for the purposes of harm (eg a state power collects DNA from a targeted individual).
Individuals suffer psychic harm from discovering family infidelities (this is so common already that it is "baked in" to consent).
The following examples do count as positive resolutions:
Evidence of discrimination or insurance rates being set from individual-level genomics without explicit customer authorization ("would you like to submit your DNA profile to Anthem?"), even if legal and authorized under a vague terms of service
An outside actor gaining access to genomics data, learning about family infidelities, and publishing this broadly.

P.title: Will there be Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves as YES if the machine system outscores at least two of the three humans on the following test prior to 2040, or NO otherwise. If no such tests are conducted, resolves as AMBIGUOUS.
Assume that prior to 2040, a generalized intelligence test will be administered as follows. A team of three expert interviewers will interact with a candidate machine system (MS) and three humans (3H). The humans will be graduate students in each of physics, mathematics and computer science from one of the top 25 research universities (per some recognized list), chosen independently of the interviewers. The interviewers will electronically communicate (via text, image, spoken word, or other means) an identical series of exam questions of their choosing over a period of two hours to the MS and 3H, designed to advantage the 3H. Both MS and 3H have full access to the internet, but no party is allowed to consult additional humans, and we assume the MS is not an internet-accessible resource. The exam will be scored blindly by a disinterested third party.
Note that this also effectively tests whether the internet as a whole functions as a human-level intelligence, in that a positive resolution indicates that the human participants are effectively superfluous.

P.title: Will a non-state actor have acquired a nuclear weapon from a state by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, between this question opening and 2030-01-01, an individual or group who is not in a state's nuclear chain of command has possession of a nuclear weapon that was originally developed by a state and is in deployable condition at the time the state acquires it (though it need not be used, detonated, or set on alert). This may occur (for example) by sales, theft, or a state inadvertently losing control of a weapon. This will not include cases where a non-state actor independently develops a weapon (such scenarios are addressed in a separate question).
A non-state actor obtaining highly-enriched uranium or other weapons material is not sufficient to resolve this question positively. Additionally, dirty bombs (conventional weapons which use radioactive material to spread fallout) do not qualify for this question; the weapon must be a nuclear weapon in the sense of having nuclear fission or fusion as its primary energy source.
This question will resolve on the basis of official statements by governments, government intelligence authorities, or non-governmental nuclear intelligence organizations. In the case of significant disagreement or ambiguity on the points above, resolution may be delayed until 2035-01-01 for clarification, or be resolved ambiguous at the discretion of Metaculus admins

para_P.title: By the year 2030, will a non-state entity have obtained a nuclear weapon from a sovereign state?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This inquiry will be deemed affirmative if, from the time this question is posed until January 1, 2030, an individual or organization that is not part of a state's nuclear command structure possesses a nuclear weapon that was initially created by a state and is in a condition suitable for deployment at the point it is acquired (it does not have to be utilized, detonated, or placed on alert). This could happen, for instance, through transactions, theft, or a state unintentionally losing control of a weapon. Cases where a non-state entity independently creates a weapon are excluded from this question (such scenarios are covered in a different inquiry).
Acquisition of highly-enriched uranium or other nuclear materials by a non-state actor does not suffice to affirm this question. Furthermore, the use of dirty bombs (conventional explosives that utilize radioactive materials to disseminate fallout) does not meet the criteria for this question; the weapon must be classified as a nuclear weapon, defined by nuclear fission or fusion being its primary energy source.
The resolution of this question will rely on official declarations from governments, intelligence agencies, or independent nuclear intelligence organizations. Should there be significant disputes or uncertainties regarding the aforementioned points, the resolution may be postponed until January 1, 2035, for further clarification, or may be declared ambiguous at the discretion of Metaculus administrators.

P.title: Will SpaceX land anything on Mars before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a SpaceX-branded mission, where the primary launch hardware and Mars entry, descent, and landing systems are built by SpaceX, successfully lands on the surface of Mars by January 1, 2030. A landing's "success" will be judged by the intent of the mission according to SpaceX.
A "SpaceX-branded" mission is defined to mean that the SpaceX-associated logos on the spacecraft involved (both the boosters and the Mars-bound craft) have a larger surface area than the logos of any other entity

P.title: Will the FDA or EMA withdraw approval of Semaglutide for the treatment of obesity by 2027?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if either the US Food and Drug Administration or the European Medicines Agency withdraw approval for Semaglutide (AKA Wegovy, Ozempic, or any other brand name for semaglutide 2.4 mg weekly injection) by 2027-01-01. The stated reason for withdrawal must include concerns of safety or harmful side effects

P.title: If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations, will humanity's population be less than 400 million 50 years later?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, 50 years after the final detonation as part of the first nuclear conflict (before January 1, 2100) which involves >1,000 offensive nuclear detonations, humanity's population is below 400 million. This would include, but is not limited to, scenarios in which humanity is extinct. The resolution of this question is not affected by whether, 50 years after the final detonation, the population is stable, rising, or falling; it is only affected by whether it is below 400 million.
This question will resolve as Ambiguous if there is no nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations by January 1, 2100.
For the purposes of this question, "humans" will be considered members of a species who could typically reproduce with typical 2021 humans without medical assistance. In scenarios where this question would resolve positively given that definition, but there remain >400 million beings that at least one 2021 Metaculus moderator would consider "human" (possible examples: some human-like digital minds; some possible types of genetically altered humans), this question will instead resolve ambiguously. This is because it is debatable whether such scenarios should count as population collapses.
Fine Print
No attempt will be made to distinguish the effects of the nuclear conflict from the effects of other events. That is, even if it's mere coincidence that the population declines and/or that it remains low following the nuclear conflict, the question can still resolve positively.
We request that you forecast your true beliefs despite the fact that a Metaculus scores may be unlikely to be tracked or cared about if this question resolves positively, given that forecasts on this question may play a role in informing important decisions.

P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will receive an affirmative answer if, fifty years after the last detonation in the initial nuclear war (before January 1, 2100) involving more than 1,000 nuclear explosions, the total human population worldwide is less than 400 million. This includes scenarios where humanity might be entirely extinct. The resolution is not influenced by whether the population is stable, increasing, or decreasing fifty years after the final detonation; it strictly depends on whether it is below 400 million.
This question will be categorized as Ambiguous if no nuclear war with over 1,000 detonations occurs by January 1, 2100.
For this question, "humans" refers to individuals of a species that can reproduce with typical humans from 2021 without any medical assistance. In cases where this question would be positively resolved based on that definition, but there are over 400 million entities that at least one Metaculus moderator from 2021 would consider as "human" (such as certain human-like digital beings; particular types of genetically modified humans), the question will be deemed ambiguous. This is due to the debatable nature of whether such scenarios should be interpreted as population declines.
Fine Print
No effort will be made to differentiate the effects of the nuclear war from other events. Even if the reduction in population and/or its low level post-nuclear conflict is coincidental, the question can still achieve a positive resolution.
We encourage you to forecast your true beliefs despite the possibility that Metaculus scores may not be tracked or considered if this question resolves positively, as predictions on this issue could impact significant decisions.

P.title: Will a non-test nuclear detonation by a non-state actor cause at least one fatality by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A nuclear detonation by a non-state actor could potentially have dire consequences either directly or via triggering other harmful actions by other actors. Non-state actors have never yet detonated nuclear weapons, but there are conceivable scenarios in which they could:
The majority of nuclear security experts identify two primary scenarios involving nuclear weapons and non-state actors. The first scenario involves the acquisition of a nuclear device from the existing arsenals of nuclear-armed States by terrorists or other non-state actors. The second scenario envisions the construction of a crude nuclear bomb by non-state actors using special nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). The actualization of each of these scenarios would be very difficult, and the probability of a successful theft and detonation of an actual nuclear weapon or manufacturing of an improvised device by non-state actors is considered to be low. Yet, this probability is not zero.
Will a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor causes at least one fatality by 2030?
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor causes at least one fatality in any country or area globally.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation, so a fatality caused by things like fallout, rioting, or climate effects will not count towards a positive resolution.
Resolution criteria will be gathered from reliable news sources or from direct government or multi-national reports such as from the UN.
Neither detonations for testing purposes nor peaceful nuclear explosions will count towards question resolution, even if such detonations cause substantial damage.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to the resolution council or Metaculus admins.

P.title: Will a non-test nuclear detonation by a non-state actor cause at least one fatality by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A nuclear detonation by a non-state actor could potentially have dire consequences either directly or via triggering other harmful actions by other actors. Non-state actors have never yet detonated nuclear weapons, but there are conceivable scenarios in which they could:
The majority of nuclear security experts identify two primary scenarios involving nuclear weapons and non-state actors. The first scenario involves the acquisition of a nuclear device from the existing arsenals of nuclear-armed States by terrorists or other non-state actors. The second scenario envisions the construction of a crude nuclear bomb by non-state actors using special nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). The actualization of each of these scenarios would be very difficult, and the probability of a successful theft and detonation of an actual nuclear weapon or manufacturing of an improvised device by non-state actors is considered to be low. para_P.title: Could a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor lead to at least one fatality before 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A nuclear detonation by a non-state actor could have dire consequences either directly or by provoking additional harmful actions from other entities. Historically, non-state actors have not set off nuclear weapons, but there are credible situations where this might happen:
Most nuclear security experts acknowledge two primary scenarios involving nuclear weapons and non-state actors. The first scenario involves terrorists or other non-state groups acquiring a nuclear device from the existing arsenals of nuclear-capable countries. The second scenario envisions non-state actors developing a basic nuclear bomb using special nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). The realization of either scenario would be extremely difficult, and the probability of a successful theft and detonation of an actual nuclear weapon or the creation of an improvised device by non-state actors is considered low. However, this probability is not zero.
Could a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor lead to at least one fatality by the year 2030?
This question will receive a Yes answer if, before January 1, 2030, a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor results in at least one death in any country or region globally.
The fatality must be a direct result of the explosion, meaning deaths from fallout, civil unrest, or environmental consequences will not be counted towards a positive resolution.
Resolution criteria will be derived from reputable news sources or official government or international reports such as those from the UN.
Detonations for research purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions will not be taken into account for question resolution, even if such detonations cause considerable damage.
Research detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as those claimed as tests or peaceful nuclear explosions by an official government statement within 30 days of the event, unless contested by credible media, governmental reports, or international reports. para_P.title: Could a nuclear explosion caused by a non-state group result in at least one death before 2030?
para_P.body:
Criteria for Resolution
A nuclear explosion carried out by a non-state organization could have severe consequences, either directly or by triggering additional harmful actions. Although non-state groups have never detonated nuclear weapons, plausible scenarios exist where they might:
Most nuclear security experts identify two main scenarios involving nuclear weapons and non-state groups. The first scenario involves terrorists or other non-state actors obtaining a nuclear weapon from the stockpiles of nuclear-armed countries. The second scenario entails non-state groups creating a rudimentary nuclear bomb using specific nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). Both scenarios pose significant challenges, and the likelihood of successfully stealing and detonating an actual nuclear weapon or manufacturing an improvised device by non-state actors is considered low. However, this likelihood is not zero.
Could a nuclear explosion by a non-state entity lead to at least one fatality by 2030?
This question will receive an affirmative answer if, before January 1, 2030, a nuclear explosion by a non-state actor results in at least one death anywhere in the world.
The fatality must arise from the immediate aftermath of the explosion; therefore, deaths resulting from fallout, civil disorder, or climate effects will not be counted towards a positive resolution.
Resolution criteria will be based on credible news outlets or official government or international reports, such as those from the UN.
Explosions conducted for testing or peaceful purposes will not be counted towards the resolution of the question, even if they cause significant damage.
Test explosions and peaceful nuclear detonations are defined as those recognized as tests or peaceful nuclear detonations by an official government announcement within 30 days of the event, without contradiction from credible media, state reports, or international reports. P.title: Could a nuclear blast initiated by a non-governmental organization result in at least one death by the year 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A nuclear explosion carried out by a non-governmental organization could have severe consequences, either directly or by triggering further harmful actions. Although non-state actors have yet to detonate nuclear devices, there are plausible scenarios where they might:
Most specialists in nuclear security highlight two main scenarios regarding nuclear weapons and non-state actors. The first scenario involves terrorists or similar groups obtaining a nuclear device from the stockpiles of nuclear-armed countries. The second scenario entails non-state actors constructing a rudimentary nuclear bomb using special nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). Both scenarios pose significant difficulties, and the likelihood of successfully stealing and detonating an actual nuclear weapon or creating an improvised device by non-state actors is considered low. However, this likelihood is not entirely absent.
Could a nuclear explosion by a non-governmental entity result in at least one fatality by 2030?
This question will be answered in the affirmative if, before January 1, 2030, a nuclear detonation by a non-state entity leads to at least one death anywhere in the world.
The fatality must arise from the immediate effects of the explosion; thus, deaths due to fallout, civil unrest, or environmental changes will not be counted towards a positive outcome.
Resolution criteria will be based on credible news outlets or direct reports from governmental or international organizations, including those from the UN.
Detonations conducted for experimental purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions will not be considered in the resolution of this question, even if they result in significant destruction.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are identified as those recognized as tests or peaceful nuclear explosions by an official government announcement within 30 days of the event, without contradiction from trustworthy media, state reports, or international reports. If the information is unclear, the resolution will be determined by the resolution council or Metaculus administrators.

P.title: In 2029, will the US have 3,800 or fewer nuclear weapons?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The size of the US's nuclear weapons stockpile reached a peak in 1966 at around 30,000 warheads. Following the deescalation and the end of the Cold War, the number has substantially decreased. Kristensen and Korda (2019) estimate that the US maintains a deployed stockpile of nearly 3,800 warheads. The approximate breakdown is as follows:
1,750 warheads are currently deployed, of which
1,300 strategic warheads are deployed on ballistic missiles,
300 at strategic bomber bases in the United States,
150 tactical bombs are deployed at air bases in Europe.
2,050 are in storage as a so-called hedge against technical or geopolitical surprises.
It is possible that this trend will reverse in a period of nuclear rearmament, especially if world tensions get worse. The Trump Administration’s Nuclear Posture Review takes a confrontational tone, presenting an assertive posture that embraces “Great Power competition” and includes plans to expand the US' nuclear arsenal.
In 2029, will the US have 3,800 or fewer nuclear weapons?
This resolves positive if credible sources, such as the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists' Nuclear Notebook (such as this one for 2019) reports that the US held 3,800 (or fewer) nuclear warheads at any time in 2029. A similar credible source may be consulted if the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists in no longer active or publishing reports. For the purposes of question resolution, warheads that are retired and awaiting dismantlement will not be counted.
See also the related question, If the US does not pursue nuclear disarmament, how many nuclear warheads will it have in 2029?

para_P.title: By the year 2029, will the United States possess 3,800 or fewer nuclear warheads?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The peak of the US's nuclear arsenal occurred in 1966, with an estimated 30,000 warheads. Since the end of the Cold War and subsequent de-escalation, this number has significantly declined. According to Kristensen and Korda (2019), the US currently has a deployed stockpile of approximately 3,800 warheads, broken down as follows:
1,750 warheads are actively deployed, which include:
1,300 strategic warheads positioned on ballistic missiles,
300 located at strategic bomber bases within the United States,
150 tactical bombs stationed at air bases in Europe.
Additionally, 2,050 warheads are kept in storage as a precaution against unforeseen technical or geopolitical events.
There is a possibility that this downward trend could reverse if a period of nuclear rearmament occurs, particularly in response to escalating global tensions. The Nuclear Posture Review from the Trump Administration adopts a confrontational stance, indicating a willingness to engage in “Great Power competition” and outlining plans to bolster the US nuclear arsenal.
By the year 2029, will the United States have 3,800 or fewer nuclear warheads?
This question is considered affirmative if credible sources, such as the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists' Nuclear Notebook (for instance, this one from 2019), indicate that the US had 3,800 (or fewer) nuclear warheads at any point during 2029. In the event that the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists ceases to operate or publish, a similar credible source may be utilized. For the purpose of resolving this question, warheads that are retired and pending dismantlement will not be included in the count.
Refer also to the related inquiry, If the US does not pursue nuclear disarmament, what will be the number of nuclear warheads in 2029?

P.title: Will the US possess 3,800 or fewer nuclear warheads in 2029?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The US's nuclear weapons stockpile peaked in 1966 at approximately 30,000 warheads. Since the end of the Cold War, this number has significantly declined. According to Kristensen and Korda (2019), the US currently has an active stockpile of nearly 3,800 warheads. The estimated distribution is as follows:
1,750 warheads are actively deployed, including
1,300 strategic warheads on ballistic missiles,
300 at strategic bomber bases within the US,
150 tactical bombs at air bases in Europe.
Additionally, 2,050 warheads are stored as a precaution against technical or geopolitical uncertainties.

Will the United States possess 3,800 or fewer nuclear warheads by 2029?
This question will receive an affirmative response if reputable sources, such as the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists' Nuclear Notebook (like the 2019 version), report that the US had 3,800 (or fewer) nuclear warheads at any point during 2029. If the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists stops functioning or publishing, a similar credible source may be used instead. For resolution purposes, retired warheads that are pending dismantlement will not be included.

P.title: By 2029, will the United States have 3,800 or fewer nuclear warheads?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The highest number of nuclear warheads in the US arsenal was recorded in 1966, peaking at approximately 30,000. Since the end of the Cold War, this amount has significantly declined. According to Kristensen and Korda (2019), the current active stockpile stands at nearly 3,800 warheads. The estimated distribution includes:
1,750 warheads that are actively deployed, which comprises
1,300 strategic warheads on ballistic missiles,
300 located at strategic bomber bases within the US,
150 tactical bombs at airbases in Europe.
Additionally, 2,050 warheads are stored as a precaution against technical or geopolitical risks.
This trend could reverse if there is a renewed focus on nuclear armament, particularly amidst escalating global tensions. The Nuclear Posture Review from the Trump Administration takes a confrontational stance, emphasizing “Great Power competition” and suggesting a potential increase in the US nuclear arsenal.

This question will receive an affirmative response if reputable sources, such as the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists' Nuclear Notebook (like the 2019 version), report that the US had 3,800 (or fewer) nuclear warheads at any point during 2029. If the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists stops functioning or publishing, a similar credible source may be used instead. For resolution purposes, retired warheads that are pending dismantlement will not be included.

P.title: Will the WTA and ATP merge before 2031?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both men and women play as part of one tour with one tour organiser in top competitive Tennis. It will also resolve as Yes if not all tournaments are mixed (ie if some currently all-female or all-male tournaments are part of the tour, that doesn't trigger negative resolution as long as the overarching tour organiser is one body)
This question will resolve as No if men and women play as part of two separate tours on the basis of gender.
In the event that it is unclear (eg the tennis tour fractures into multiple tours (WTA, ATP, mixed tour)) we will ask Jeff Sackmann's opinion and resolve at his discretion. (In the event he says it's unclear / is uncontactable / unwilling to decide, the question will resolve as Ambiguous

para_P.title: Is there a possibility of the WTA and ATP combining before the year 2031?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be answered affirmatively if both male and female players participate under a single tour with a unified tour management in elite competitive Tennis. It will also be considered a Yes if not every tournament is co-ed (i.e., if some tournaments exclusively for women or men are included in the tour, it won't result in a negative resolution as long as the primary tour management is a single entity).
This question will be marked as No if male and female players compete under two distinct tours based on gender.
If the situation is ambiguous (for instance, if the tennis tour splits into multiple tours such as WTA, ATP, and a mixed tour), we will seek the judgment of Jeff Sackmann, who will make the final decision. If he finds it unclear or is unreachable or unwilling to provide a decision, the question will be deemed Ambiguous.

P.title: Will humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Since October 31 2000, the date Soyuz TM-31 lifted off from the Baikonur Cosmodrome carrying the members of Expedition 1, the first long-duration ISS crew, humanity has maintained a permanent off-Earth presence for more than 19 years.
This question asks: Will humanity maintain an off-Earth presence continuously until 1 January 2050?
For a positive resolution, at least one living and conscious biological human must be physically located at some point beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until 1 January 2050. This could include persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g. Moon or Mars explorers / settlers).
If the number of living and conscious biological humans off-Earth drops to zero at any time before 1 January 2050, this question resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count for the purposes of this question. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious for the purposes of this question.
However, biological humans with some degree of cybernetic augmentation (brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc) will suffice, so long as they could still reproduce with un-augmented humans.

para_P.title: Will humanity sustain an uninterrupted off-planet presence until the year 2050?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Since the launch of Soyuz TM-31 on October 31, 2000, which carried the first long-term crew of the ISS, Expedition 1, humanity has successfully maintained a continuous off-planet presence for over 19 years.
This inquiry seeks to determine: Will humanity uphold an off-planet presence without interruption until January 1, 2050?
To achieve a positive outcome, there must always be at least one living and aware biological human located at some point beyond 100 kilometers above Earth's average sea level at all times leading up to January 1, 2050. This could involve individuals on spacecraft and space stations, as well as those on any celestial body other than Earth (e.g., explorers or settlers on the Moon or Mars).
If the number of living and aware biological humans off-planet falls to zero at any moment before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve negatively. Entities such as EMs, AI systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and any other forms of non-biological or non-aware humans will not be counted for this inquiry. Humans who are simply asleep will be regarded as conscious for this question.
Nevertheless, biological humans with some level of cybernetic enhancement (such as brain implants, artificial limbs, or organs, etc.) will be acceptable, provided they retain the ability to reproduce with non-enhanced humans.

para_P.title: Will humanity sustain an uninterrupted off-Earth presence until the year 2050?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Since the launch of Soyuz TM-31 on October 31, 2000, which transported the first long-term crew of the ISS, known as Expedition 1, humanity has had a continuous off-Earth presence for over 19 years.
This inquiry seeks to determine: Will humanity uphold an off-Earth presence without interruption until January 1, 2050?
For a positive outcome, there must be at least one living, aware biological human located at a point beyond 100 kilometers above Earth's average sea level at all times continuously until January 1, 2050. This includes individuals on spacecraft and space stations, as well as those on any celestial body other than Earth (such as explorers or settlers on the Moon or Mars).
If the count of living, aware biological humans off-Earth falls to zero at any moment prior to January 1, 2050, this question will resolve negatively. Entities such as EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and any other forms that are entirely non-biological or non-conscious will not be considered for this question. Humans who are simply asleep will be deemed conscious for this inquiry.
Nevertheless, biological humans with some level of cybernetic enhancement (such as brain implants, artificial limbs, or organs) will qualify, provided they are still capable of reproduction with un-augmented humans.

For a favorable outcome, at least one living, conscious biological human must be physically situated at some point more than 100 kilometers above Earth's average sea level at all times without interruption until January 1, 2050. This encompasses individuals aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as those on any celestial body other than Earth (for instance, explorers or settlers on the Moon or Mars).
If the number of living, conscious biological humans off-planet falls to zero at any moment before January 1, 2050, this question will be answered in the negative. Entities such as EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and any other forms of either entirely non-biological or non-conscious humans will not be considered for this question. Humans who are merely sleeping will be regarded as conscious for the purposes of this inquiry.
However, biological humans with some degree of cybernetic enhancement (such as brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc.) will be deemed acceptable, as long as they maintain the capacity to reproduce with un-augmented humans.

Nonetheless, biological humans with some level of cybernetic enhancement (such as brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc.) will be accepted, provided they maintain the capacity to reproduce with un-augmented humans.

para_P.title: Will humanity sustain an unbroken presence beyond Earth until the year 2050?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Since the launch of Soyuz TM-31 from the Baikonur Cosmodrome on October 31, 2000, which transported the first long-term crew to the International Space Station, humans have maintained a continuous off-planet presence for over 19 years.
This question inquires: Will humanity preserve an uninterrupted extraterrestrial presence until January 1, 2050?
For a positive answer, there must always be at least one living and aware human being located beyond 100 kilometers in altitude above Earth's average sea level at all times leading up to January 1, 2050. This includes individuals aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as those on any celestial bodies outside of Earth (such as explorers or settlers on the Moon or Mars).
If the count of living and aware biological humans beyond Earth drops to zero at any point before January 1, 2050, this question will be answered negatively. Non-biological entities, artificial intelligence, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and any other forms of non-conscious beings will not be considered in this question. Humans who are merely asleep will be regarded as conscious for this purpose.
However, biological humans with some degree of cybernetic enhancement (such as brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc.) will be accepted, provided they retain the ability to reproduce with un-augmented humans.

P.title: Will Turkey be a NATO member continuously until January 1, 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Turkey is a NATO member continuously from October 1, 2019 to January 1, 2025. The question will resolve as No if Turkey is suspended or expelled from NATO, or if it withdraws of its own accord, at any time before January 1, 2025.
If before this question resolves NATO is dissolved, or changed in structure or operation so substantially that Metaculus administrators believe it is no longer prudent to continue this question, this question shall resolve as Ambiguous

P.title: Who will be elected to be US President in 2024? (Kamala Harris)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the person who wins the 2024 US presidential election, and No for all other options. This will be the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment.
This question is not limited to the individuals currently listed below; the question may resolve as No for all listed options, and options may be added later.
Fine Print
This question does not require that the individual winning the 2024 Election wins the popular vote, be projected by news media as winning the election, or to be officially inaugurated or perform any duty of the US President, only that they have been selected by the Electoral College or by US Congress.
In the event that there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous for all options.

The determination will rely on the person who garners the highest number of votes in the Electoral College or is chosen by Congress according to the contingency procedures outlined in the Twelfth Amendment.
This inquiry is not confined to the individuals currently mentioned; it may resolve as No for all candidates listed, and new contenders might arise later.
Fine Print
This question does not stipulate that the winner of the 2024 Election must achieve the popular vote, be announced by news organizations as the winner, or be formally inaugurated or execute any presidential duties, only that they have been appointed by the Electoral College or by the US Congress.
If there is no election or vote certification by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous for all candidates.

P.title: Will any top 10 global meat processor/producer go bankrupt before 2028?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Cargill, Tyson Foods, Hormel, Muyuan Foods, Wens Foodstuff Group, or any of their parent companies file for bankruptcy by January 1, 2028, according to credible financial media reports.
This question will resolve positively if Cargill, Tyson Foods or Hormel (or any of their parent companies) submits a court filing seeking bankruptcy protection under any provision of the United States Bankruptcy Code, or if Muyuan Foods or Wens Foodstuff Group (or any of their parent companies) apply for bankruptcy proceedings in China. It will also resolve positively if Kerry Group applies for bankruptcy proceedings in Ireland, JBS in Brazil, the WH Group in Hong Kong, Mowi ASA in Norway, or the Marubeni Corporation in Japan.
Positive resolution requires a filing only. No court ruling needs to be made.
If any of the relevant companies are acquired or merged, and the new entity files for bankruptcy within two years of the acquisition or merger, the question will resolve positively

P.title: Will any top 10 global meat processor/producer go bankrupt before 2028?
P.body:
